Typhoon Damrey made landfall over Vietnam during day of November 04, 2017 and it rapidly weakened, and fully dissipated on November 5. Damrey was the strongest typhoon to strike southern Vietnam since 2001's Typhoon Lingling. The following heavy rainfall causing widespread flood in 10 provinces in the middle of Vietnam.
The latest damages reported in the Tele-conference, chaired by the Vietnam Prime Minister held in late afternoon of November 6, 2017, was that: at least 64 people had been killed in Vietnam as a result of the typhoon, with another 27 missing, including 9 sailors from ships that sank off the coast during the storm. Widespread flooding was reported, with more than 140,000 homes having been destroyed or damaged. The beach resort of Nha Trang City, Khanh Hoa province was among the worst hit areas, 30,000 inhabitants and tourists had to be evacuated from the area. The total losses estimated around 500 million USD.
Khanh Hoa province, the center of the typhoon hit, was the most devastated area. Requested for the support from the central government: 25,000 tons of rice; 1,115 billion VND (50 million USD) for recovery
